'''Nandini''' (or the '''[[wikipedia:Dryads|dryads]]''') were the [[fays]] of the valleys,<ref group=note>In the ''[[Gnomish Lexicon]]'', they were the "fays of the country" instead.</ref><ref name=Ndr/> according to the early version of the [[legendarium]] in ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]''.<ref>{{PE|14}}, "[[The Creatures of the Earth]]", p. 10</ref>

They arrived to the world with [[Aulë]] and [[Yavanna]], along with many other types of fays.<ref>{{LT1|III}}, p. 66</ref>

== Etymology ==
The name ''Nandini'' is in [[Qenya]], being the plural form of ''nandin'' ("dryad");<ref name=Nan>{{PE|12}}, entry '''NAŘA''', p. 64</ref> the [[Gnomish]] cognate of ''nandin'' was '''''nandir'''''.<ref name=Ndr/>

The word ''nandin'' is most likely related to the word ''[[nan(d)]]'' ("woodland"), which was derived from the root [[NAŘA]].<ref name=Nan/><ref>{{PE|14}}, "[[The Creatures of the Earth]]", note 13, p. 7</ref> See also the related Gnomish words ''[[nand (Gnomish word)|nand]]'' or ''[[nann]]'' ("a field acre").<ref name=Ndr>{{PE|11}}, entries '''nand, nann''' and '''nandir''', p. 59</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In a later version of the legendarium from ''[[The Etymologies]]'' (1930s), the term "dryad" is instead applied to the ''[[tavari]]'', a related group of beings.<ref>{{LR|P3}}, entry '''TÁWAR'''-, p. 391</ref>
